Apple___Apple_scab.cause: Fungal infection caused by Venturia inaequalis
Apple___Apple_scab.symptoms: Olive-green to brown velvety spots on leaves and fruit
Apple___Apple_scab.treatment: Apply fungicides (captan or myclobutanil). Remove and destroy infected leaves. Ensure good air circulation.
Apple___Apple_scab.prevention: Plant resistant varieties. Rake and dispose of fallen leaves in autumn.

Apple___Black_rot.cause: Fungal infection caused by Botryosphaeria obtusa
Apple___Black_rot.symptoms: Brown rotting lesions on fruit, purple spots on leaves, cankers on branches
Apple___Black_rot.treatment: Prune infected branches 8–12 inches below visible infection. Apply copper-based fungicide.
Apple___Black_rot.prevention: Remove mummified fruits. Avoid wounding the tree. Maintain tree vigor.

Apple___Cedar_apple_rust.cause: Fungal infection caused by Gymnosporangium juniperi-virginianae
Apple___Cedar_apple_rust.symptoms: Bright orange or yellow spots on upper leaf surface with tube-like structures underneath
Apple___Cedar_apple_rust.treatment: Apply fungicides (myclobutanil) at bud break. Remove nearby juniper/cedar host plants.
Apple___Cedar_apple_rust.prevention: Plant resistant apple varieties. Avoid planting near junipers.

Apple___healthy.symptoms: Leaf appears healthy with no visible symptoms
Apple___healthy.prevention: Maintain regular watering, fertilization, and pruning practices.

Blueberry___healthy.symptoms: Leaf appears healthy with no visible symptoms
Blueberry___healthy.prevention: Ensure acidic soil (pH 4.5–5.5). Regular watering and mulching.

Cherry_(including_sour)___Powdery_mildew.cause: Fungal infection caused by Podosphaera clandestina
Cherry_(including_sour)___Powdery_mildew.symptoms: White powdery coating on leaves, shoots, and fruit surfaces
Cherry_(including_sour)___Powdery_mildew.treatment: Apply sulfur-based or potassium bicarbonate fungicides. Remove heavily infected tissue.
Cherry_(including_sour)___Powdery_mildew.prevention: Improve air circulation. Avoid overhead irrigation. Plant resistant varieties.

Cherry_(including_sour)___healthy.symptoms: Leaf appears healthy with no visible symptoms
Cherry_(including_sour)___healthy.prevention: Regular pruning for air circulation. Avoid overhead watering.

Corn_(maize)___Cercospora_leaf_spot Gray.cause: Fungal infection caused by Cercospora zeae-maydis
Corn_(maize)___Cercospora_leaf_spot Gray.symptoms: Rectangular gray to tan lesions running parallel to leaf veins
Corn_(maize)___Cercospora_leaf_spot Gray.treatment: Apply foliar fungicides (strobilurins or triazoles). Crop rotation recommended.
Corn_(maize)___Cercospora_leaf_spot Gray.prevention: Plant resistant hybrids. Rotate crops. Till infected residue.

Corn_(maize)___Common_rust_.cause: Fungal infection caused by Puccinia sorghi
Corn_(maize)___Common_rust_.symptoms: Small, circular to elongated cinnamon-brown pustules on both leaf surfaces
Corn_(maize)___Common_rust_.treatment: Apply fungicides early if infection is severe. Most mature plants tolerate moderate rust.
Corn_(maize)___Common_rust_.prevention: Plant resistant hybrids. Early planting can help avoid peak rust season.

Corn_(maize)___Northern_Leaf_Blight.cause: Fungal infection caused by Exserohilum turcicum
Corn_(maize)___Northern_Leaf_Blight.symptoms: Long, elliptical gray-green to tan lesions (1–6 inches) on leaves
Corn_(maize)___Northern_Leaf_Blight.treatment: Apply fungicides at tasseling stage. Use strobilurin or triazole-based fungicides.
Corn_(maize)___Northern_Leaf_Blight.prevention: Plant resistant hybrids. Crop rotation. Bury or incorporate infected debris.

Corn_(maize)___healthy.symptoms: Leaf appears healthy with no visible symptoms
Corn_(maize)___healthy.prevention: Balanced fertilization, adequate spacing, and proper irrigation.

Grape___Black_rot.cause: Fungal infection caused by Guignardia bidwellii
Grape___Black_rot.symptoms: Tan to brown circular leaf spots with dark borders; fruit shrivels into black mummies
Grape___Black_rot.treatment: Apply fungicides (mancozeb, myclobutanil) from bud break through fruit set. Remove mummified fruit.
Grape___Black_rot.prevention: Remove and destroy infected plant material. Ensure good air circulation.

Grape___Esca_(Black_Measles).cause: Complex fungal disease involving Phaeomoniella chlamydospora and others
Grape___Esca_(Black_Measles).symptoms: Tiger-stripe patterns on leaves, dark spots on berries, internal wood discoloration
Grape___Esca_(Black_Measles).treatment: No complete cure. Remove and burn infected wood. Apply trunk wound protectants.
Grape___Esca_(Black_Measles).prevention: Protect pruning wounds. Use certified disease-free planting material.

Grape___Leaf_blight_(Isariopsis_Leaf_Spo.cause: Fungal infection caused by Isariopsis clavispora
Grape___Leaf_blight_(Isariopsis_Leaf_Spo.symptoms: Dark brown irregular spots on leaves, often with yellow halos
Grape___Leaf_blight_(Isariopsis_Leaf_Spo.treatment: Apply copper-based or mancozeb fungicides. Remove infected leaves.
Grape___Leaf_blight_(Isariopsis_Leaf_Spo.prevention: Improve vineyard air circulation. Avoid leaf wetness.

Grape___healthy.symptoms: Leaf appears healthy with no visible symptoms
Grape___healthy.prevention: Regular pruning, canopy management, and balanced fertilization.

Orange___Haunglongbing_(Citrus_greening).cause: Bacterial infection (Candidatus Liberibacter asiaticus) spread by Asian citrus psyllid
Orange___Haunglongbing_(Citrus_greening).symptoms: Yellow shoots, blotchy mottled leaves, lopsided bitter fruit, premature fruit drop
Orange___Haunglongbing_(Citrus_greening).treatment: No cure exists. Remove and destroy infected trees to prevent spread. Control psyllid populations.
Orange___Haunglongbing_(Citrus_greening).prevention: Use certified disease-free nursery stock. Monitor and control psyllid insects.

Peach___Bacterial_spot.cause: Bacterial infection caused by Xanthomonas arboricola pv. pruni
Peach___Bacterial_spot.symptoms: Small, water-soaked lesions on leaves turning brown with yellow halos; cracked fruit spots
Peach___Bacterial_spot.treatment: Apply copper-based bactericides during early season. Avoid overhead irrigation.
Peach___Bacterial_spot.prevention: Plant resistant varieties. Avoid wetting foliage. Good orchard sanitation.

Peach___healthy.symptoms: Leaf appears healthy with no visible symptoms
Peach___healthy.prevention: Proper pruning, adequate spacing, and balanced nutrition.

Pepper,_bell___Bacterial_spot.cause: Bacterial infection caused by Xanthomonas campestris pv. vesicatoria
Pepper,_bell___Bacterial_spot.symptoms: Water-soaked spots on leaves turning brown with yellow margins; raised scabby fruit lesions
Pepper,_bell___Bacterial_spot.treatment: Apply copper-based bactericides. Remove and destroy severely infected plants.
Pepper,_bell___Bacterial_spot.prevention: Use certified disease-free seed. Avoid overhead irrigation. Rotate crops.

Pepper,_bell___healthy.symptoms: Leaf appears healthy with no visible symptoms
Pepper,_bell___healthy.prevention: Consistent watering, good drainage, and crop rotation every 2–3 years.

Potato___Early_blight.cause: Fungal infection caused by Alternaria solani
Potato___Early_blight.symptoms: Dark brown concentric ring spots (target-board pattern) on older lower leaves
Potato___Early_blight.treatment: Apply fungicides (chlorothalonil or mancozeb). Remove and destroy infected foliage.
Potato___Early_blight.prevention: Crop rotation. Avoid overhead irrigation. Plant certified seed potatoes.

Potato___Late_blight.cause: Oomycete pathogen Phytophthora infestans (caused the Irish Potato Famine)
Potato___Late_blight.symptoms: Water-soaked pale green spots rapidly turning brown-black; white mold on leaf undersides
Potato___Late_blight.treatment: Apply fungicides (chlorothalonil, mancozeb). Destroy infected plant material immediately.
Potato___Late_blight.prevention: Plant resistant varieties. Avoid wet foliage. Destroy volunteer potato plants.

Potato___healthy.symptoms: Leaf appears healthy with no visible symptoms
Potato___healthy.prevention: Use certified seed potatoes. Proper hilling and irrigation management.

Raspberry___healthy.symptoms: Leaf appears healthy with no visible symptoms
Raspberry___healthy.prevention: Annual cane pruning and good air circulation between plants.

Soybean___healthy.symptoms: Leaf appears healthy with no visible symptoms
Soybean___healthy.prevention: Crop rotation and balanced soil fertility management.

Squash___Powdery_mildew.cause: Fungal infection caused by Podosphaera xanthii or Erysiphe cichoracearum
Squash___Powdery_mildew.symptoms: White powdery spots on upper leaf surface spreading to cover entire leaf
Squash___Powdery_mildew.treatment: Apply potassium bicarbonate, neem oil, or sulfur-based fungicides. Remove severely infected leaves.
Squash___Powdery_mildew.prevention: Plant resistant varieties. Ensure good air circulation. Avoid excess nitrogen fertilizer.

Strawberry___Leaf_scorch.cause: Fungal infection caused by Diplocarpon earlianum
Strawberry___Leaf_scorch.symptoms: Small, dark purple irregular spots that enlarge; leaf edges appear scorched or burnt
Strawberry___Leaf_scorch.treatment: Apply fungicides (captan or myclobutanil). Remove old infected leaves after harvest.
Strawberry___Leaf_scorch.prevention: Avoid overhead irrigation. Renovate beds annually. Plant resistant varieties.

Strawberry___healthy.symptoms: Leaf appears healthy with no visible symptoms
Strawberry___healthy.prevention: Renovate beds annually. Proper plant spacing and mulching.

Tomato___Bacterial_spot.cause: Bacterial infection caused by Xanthomonas vesicatoria
Tomato___Bacterial_spot.symptoms: Small, water-soaked circular spots on leaves with yellow halos; scabby raised fruit lesions
Tomato___Bacterial_spot.treatment: Apply copper-based bactericides weekly. Remove and destroy infected plant material.
Tomato___Bacterial_spot.prevention: Use disease-free seed. Avoid working in wet plants. Crop rotation.

Tomato___Early_blight.cause: Fungal infection caused by Alternaria solani
Tomato___Early_blight.symptoms: Concentric dark brown rings (bullseye pattern) on older lower leaves; stem cankers
Tomato___Early_blight.treatment: Apply fungicides (chlorothalonil or copper). Remove lower infected leaves.
Tomato___Early_blight.prevention: Mulch around plants. Avoid wetting foliage. Stake plants for air circulation.

Tomato___Late_blight.symptoms: Large, irregular water-soaked gray-green spots turning brown; white fuzzy growth on undersides
Tomato___Late_blight.treatment: Apply fungicides immediately (chlorothalonil, copper). Remove and bag all infected material.
Tomato___Late_blight.prevention: Avoid overhead watering. Destroy volunteer tomato plants. Plant resistant varieties.

Tomato___Leaf_Mold.cause: Fungal infection caused by Passalora fulva
Tomato___Leaf_Mold.symptoms: Pale yellow spots on upper leaf surface; olive-green to brown velvety mold on undersides
Tomato___Leaf_Mold.treatment: Improve ventilation. Apply fungicides (chlorothalonil or copper-based). Reduce humidity.
Tomato___Leaf_Mold.prevention: Stake and prune for air circulation. Avoid overhead irrigation. Use resistant varieties.

Tomato___Septoria_leaf_spot.cause: Fungal infection caused by Septoria lycopersici
Tomato___Septoria_leaf_spot.symptoms: Small circular spots with dark brown borders and light gray centers with tiny black dots
Tomato___Septoria_leaf_spot.treatment: Apply fungicides (chlorothalonil, mancozeb). Remove infected lower leaves promptly.
Tomato___Septoria_leaf_spot.prevention: Mulch soil. Avoid overhead watering. Rotate crops. Remove plant debris.

Tomato___Spider_mites Two-spotted_spider.cause: Pest infestation by Tetranychus urticae (spider mites)
Tomato___Spider_mites Two-spotted_spider.symptoms: Tiny yellow or white stippling on leaves; fine webbing on undersides; bronzed leaf appearance
Tomato___Spider_mites Two-spotted_spider.treatment: Apply miticides or insecticidal soap. Strong water spray to dislodge mites. Introduce predatory mites.
Tomato___Spider_mites Two-spotted_spider.prevention: Maintain adequate soil moisture. Avoid dusty conditions. Monitor regularly.

Tomato___Target_Spot.cause: Fungal infection caused by Corynespora cassiicola
Tomato___Target_Spot.symptoms: Circular dark brown lesions with concentric rings (target-like) on leaves and fruit
Tomato___Target_Spot.treatment: Apply fungicides (azoxystrobin or chlorothalonil). Remove infected plant material.
Tomato___Target_Spot.prevention: Improve air circulation. Avoid overhead irrigation. Crop rotation.

Tomato___Tomato_Yellow_Leaf_Curl_Virus.cause: Viral infection (TYLCV) transmitted by whiteflies (Bemisia tabaci)
Tomato___Tomato_Yellow_Leaf_Curl_Virus.symptoms: Upward leaf curling, yellowing leaf edges, stunted growth, reduced fruit set
Tomato___Tomato_Yellow_Leaf_Curl_Virus.treatment: No cure. Remove and destroy infected plants. Control whitefly populations with insecticides.
Tomato___Tomato_Yellow_Leaf_Curl_Virus.prevention: Use resistant varieties. Install reflective mulches. Control whiteflies early.

Tomato___Tomato_mosaic_virus.cause: Viral infection (ToMV) spread by contact, tools, and insects
Tomato___Tomato_mosaic_virus.symptoms: Mosaic light/dark green mottling on leaves; leaf distortion; stunted growth
Tomato___Tomato_mosaic_virus.treatment: No cure. Remove infected plants. Disinfect all tools with 10% bleach solution.
Tomato___Tomato_mosaic_virus.prevention: Use resistant varieties. Disinfect hands and tools. Control aphid vectors.

Tomato___healthy.symptoms: Leaf appears healthy with no visible symptoms
Tomato___healthy.prevention: Consistent watering at the base, regular fertilization, and good airflow.
